urn:contentItem:5SH8-J9N1-JB20-G3WW-00000-00Visa Inc at Bank of America Merrill Lynch Global Technology Conference - Final2018-06-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:12ZLexisNexis060518a11535684.784Visa Incat Bank of AmericaMerrill LynchGlobal Technology Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Jack Forestell

Conference Call Participants

* Colin R. Ducharme

Sterling Capital Management LLC - Executive Director of Equity Opportunities & Senior Equity Analyst

* Jason Alan Kupferberg

BofAMerrill Lynch, Research Division - MD in US Equity Research & Senior Analyst

Presentation

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG, MD IN US EQUITY RESEARCH & SENIOR ANALYST, BOFAMERRILL LYNCH, RESEARCH DIVISION: Okay. Good morning, everybody. I think we're going to go ahead and get started here. I'm Jason Kupferberg, the payments processors and IT services analyst here at Bank of AmericaMerrill Lynch. And we're very excited to have Visa with us today. We have Jack Forestell, who is Chief Product Officer at the company. We also have Will Masterson representing Investor Relations.

So Jack, thanks very much for being here. We appreciate it.

JACK FORESTELL: Thanks for having me.

Questions and Answers

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: I'm going to go through a bunch of questions, and we'll certainly be looking for questions from the audience as well. So maybe just to kick off since it's kind of topical and recent on Friday, there was obviously news of a Visa service outage over in Europe. What can you tell us about what exactly happened, how it got resolved? What was kind of the root cause?

JACK FORESTELL: Sure, and I'm glad you asked it right up front, Jason. It's something we're taking incredibly seriously. And first, let me just say we view it as our job to provide the safest, most secure, most convenient, most reliable, most resilient payment services on Earth. And for a few hours on Friday in a few of our European markets, we fell short of our own high standards that we set for ourselves and the standards that our clients and our consumers set for us. Look, we have teams right now hard at work getting to every detail of exactly what happened. I know there are a lot of questions, and many of you probably have read a little about it. I can provide what I know, a little bit more context on what happened. So sometime late morning U.K. time, we had a switch failure, a hardware switch failure in our data center in Europe. Now as you recall, we recently acquired a while back Visa Europe, and we're in the process of integrating Visa Europe into Visa. The switch failure was in the legacy Visa Europe environment. As you might expect, when you have a switch failure -- we have 2 data centers in Europe in the legacy environment. When that's which failed, as you would expect, there was fail -- real-time failover to another data center. The problem occurred when that data center and the switch in that data center did not come fully up to capacity. And so what actually happened, it wasn't a hard down or an outage, it was a constriction of capacity that occurred in that second data center. And as that happened and the transactions flowed through and we were only at partial capacity, and we had variability in the latency, transactions piled up, queued up, and many transactions were either dropped or declined. The rates of that were more significant up front early in the event. And as the teams worked to bring the capacity up through the course of the day, it got better. And finally shortly after 9 p.m. British time, system returned to normal and it's been normal ever since. And as I said, we still have people working to understand better exactly why the switch failed, exactly why the secondary site didn't come up in the way that it should have.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: So it doesn't sound like it was directly related to the IT migration that's going on because you said this occurred in the legacy environment?

JACK FORESTELL: Right.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: Okay, okay. That's very helpful. Thanks for verifying it. I know that yesterday, you had some interesting announcement, the Money 20/20 in Europe, big new investment, $100 million in FinTech, and also opening up the Visa Network a bit more broadly. Maybe talk a little bit about that, what kind of motivated you guys to make the announcement and the strategic rationale behind it?

JACK FORESTELL: Sure. We're excited about it. We're open for business for FinTechs. And we've been partnering with FinTech companies in this market for some time now. We got great partnerships with companies like Square and Stripe and Marqeta, Pay -- you name it. But we want to make sure that we plant a flag out there that tells the whole world that we are open for FinTech partnership the world over. And as you're all aware, there's a lot going on right now in the European landscape with respect to open banking. Regulation is really driving a lot of activity. There are a lot of small companies out there developing great, new products and services in the payments space, and we absolutely want to partner with them. As you sort of referred to, Jason, there are 2 pieces of what we announced the other day. One piece was fast onboarding, kind of what we've internally colloquially referred to as FinTech in a box. We opened our developer center 2 years ago, exposed web services to partners. They can get on board and experiment with Visa. But we did find to get into production as a small company with Visa was just too hard. So we've created a process for fast onboarding. FinTech partners can get on the wire at Visa with this new process in less than a month. Obviously, they can get up to scale in testing and experimenting a lot faster than that. So we're excited about that. And then the second part of it was we're interested in making investments strategically in up-and-coming companies who've got great technology and great new services that are going to help us create the leading edge payment experiences that we're in the business of creating. So that's where the $100 million came from. One more data is, I keep getting asked, "Why only in Europe?" And my answer to that is, it's beginning in Europe. As I've said, we've been doing this in the U.S. for a while. We absolutely want to expand globally with everything that's going on with PSD2 and open banking in Europe. We thought it was a great place to start, but we'll expand beyond Europe very quickly.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: So let me step back for a second, ask a kind of a bigger picture question. So your title is Chief Product Officer. I think that includes oversight of all Visa's strategic partnerships. But just tell us a little bit about what are really your top 3 priorities, let's say, on your agenda in this role?

JACK FORESTELL: Yes, sure. I'll manage it in a slightly different way. But the Chief Product Officer thing is -- I'm excited about it. It's a new thing for me. And I'd say it's sort of part of our journey in moving from card network to technology platform solutions company. And so historically, we've had our assets kind of distributed throughout the company. We have of our core payment processing rails in one place, value-added services in another place, solutions teams in another place, partnership teams in another place. And what we've just done recently is we have brought that all together. And the idea is look, we're a tech platform. We got to have the best payment rails and the best underlying chassis there is in the business. We've then got to add services on top of that. So we've brought the core platform team together with the teams that are building and expanding our inventory of services. And then we also brought together the teams around the world who are working hand in glove with our clients to build solutions on top of that platform along with our partnership and business development teams. So I'm excited about bringing it all together and having one integrated vision and one integrated team for how we deliver those new solutions.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: It seems like Visa's attitude towards partnering with others in the ecosystem has evolved a bit over the last couple of years, maybe become a little bit more open, if you will. So just wanted to get your take on that. To what extent has that been kind of a conscious decision? Maybe the Visa-PayPal partnership being the best example of that over the last couple of years. So just share with us some perspective on what's driving that shift and approach at Visa? And do we expect that to continue going forward?

JACK FORESTELL: Yes, I don't know if we've sort of rethought how important partnership is at Visa. I mean, if you think of our business model, we kind of sit in the middle of thousands of partnerships that help us scale globally to 3 billion consumers and 46 million merchants. So partnership's kind of been at the core for this company's been doing for 60 years. I think what's happened in the last few years is that we're reimagining the breadth and the nature of those partnerships. It certainly still a very strong set of partnerships with our issuing banks, our acquiring banks processors. But increasingly, it's partnerships with FinTechs that we just talked about and big tech companies like PayPal, like Google, like Apple, you name it. These players are important players in the payments ecosystem and we need to be actively engaged with them. You mentioned the PayPal partnership. They're a great partner, one of the strongest partnerships that we have right now. If anything, they certainly initiate a heck of a lot of Visa payments. So we like them a lot.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: One of the products we get asked a lot about is Visa Direct. And I know that the company has started talking a little bit more about it in recent quarters. So maybe if you can just talk about sort of the road map for that product? Really how you see the use cases for Visa Direct evolving and then kind of the broader strategy that Visa has employed here, kind of building a product as opposed to making a sizable acquisition as Mastercard obviously bought Vocalink, so there's a little bit of disparity in strategy and approach there. So would love some thoughts.

JACK FORESTELL: Yes, look, we realized years ago that there are a set of use cases out there that are better served when a consumer or a small business can initiate a payment and have that payment pushed to their counterparty. Our model is typically that the consumer allows the counterparty to initiate a pull payment from their account. And that's fundamental difference between the historic payments that have gone over card networks and push payments, or what we call Visa Direct. And real-time payment platforms are growing around the world. Real-time ACH is coming to a market near you, if it's not already there, I would project it's going to be soon. And so we realized we need to offer a competitive and viable push payment service to satisfy use cases from P2P to low cost acquiring in emerging markets, you name it, there are a lot of use cases. And we stared at the assets that we had and realized, wow, if you really get down to a real-time payment platform, real-time ACH, it's essentially just a straight account to account transaction, so it's settlement service that happens in real time. We can replicate the same thing. We actually have that capability. There's a little bit of work to do on the part of our issuers in order to make it absolutely real-time, but on top of that, we then have the whole array of Visa value-added services that can run atop -- across the top of that transaction, whether it's fraud liability transaction, fraud risk monitoring, disputes, chargebacks, the whole Visa works when you kind of go over these transactions, which isn't the case with the basic account-to-account transactions. So we love Visa Direct. As a platform, we think it's a better product than what you can get with a basic ACH transaction. We're working hard on it. We've got about 1 billion cards enabled for Visa Direct right now globally. I think we're on track to be about 1.5 billion by the end of the year, probably 2 billion on into 2019. So it's -- I'd like to think that's decent scale when you get into the billions.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: And are the transaction counts kind of scaling in line with your expectations so far?

JACK FORESTELL: Yes, we're actually -- we're very much tracking along with our expectations, a lot of work with partners out there to take up the service. We got a lot of people excited about it, inventing the use cases. It's a little bit back to what I was saying before, those are core rails. We're adding a little bit of set of services specifically for those push transactions on top and then partnering with people all throughout the ecosystem to have them create new payment experiences and use cases for it. So yes, we're pretty excited about it.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: How should we think about faster ACH? Maybe let's just use the U.S. as an example since it's common, right? It's not quite here yet, but it's common. And from what we hear, maybe another 12 to 18 months, a lot of banks will actually be up and running on it. Is that going to pose a threat to Visa Direct?

JACK FORESTELL: Yes, look, I always know that competition is healthy. And so would fast ACH be viewed as a competitor to Visa Direct? Sure. But at the same, I think the advent of fast ACH in the U.S. will also create much more awareness about the ability to transfer off of check and wire and slow ACH and cash and all manner of other payments, which are really where we're trying to grab the growth from anyway. So frankly, in a way, the more the merrier. If we can raise awareness about it, I like our chances given everything I was just talking about and the value-added services that we've got in Visa Direct relative to a basic ACH payment.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: So essentially, the pie will get bigger, right? So okay. Let's switch gears and talk about the single payment button that everyone...

JACK FORESTELL: Yes, we're excited about that.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: Is very excited about. The whole secure remote commerce framework. Maybe for those who are a little bit less familiar with some of the background, maybe say a little bit about what SRC is and how Visa is participating and then ultimately, how this is expected to manifest itself in terms of a unified payment button that seems to be maybe the next evolution, if you will, of kind of Visa's online checkout strategy.

JACK FORESTELL: Yes. Well, look, here's where I'd start. I'd say if you look at what we and the ecosystem accomplished at the point of sale, right, we get tremendous scale and reach and coverage at the physical point of sale. And part of the reason that occurred was we had incredibly strong standards, right? The standards that governed the interface, how a terminal looks and felt and worked, how a card looked and felt and what it was equipped with and then how those things interoperate with each other, how consumers authenticate themselves and how the data moves through the system. Those things in the physical space were all very precisely prescribed. And that enabled everybody to know what they were doing, get together, and make the thing work at global scale. In digital commerce, the same isn't true and it hasn't been true for the whole digital commerce journey so far. And look, we've done very well at the digital commerce, when a payment transfers from face-to-face to digital, we do even better. But at the same time, it's lacked those standards to make it easy for merchants and easy for consumers. And we've been working now for years to really try to drive us in the industry to a common set of standards. So we're really excited about secure remote commerce. That's what it essentially is. It's a set of standards to help us to get to scale in digital payments. And there are 3 elements to the standard. Everyone does love talking about the button, that's an important piece. But there's a set of standards around the user experience to create commonality there, make it more easy and intuitive for consumers. They see a common button and they know that common mark, they know what to do. Easier for merchants, acquirers, gateways, carts to integrate. Integrate once instead of integrating 6 times. Makes a ton of sense, it's what happens at the physical point of sale. But it's not just the user experience standards, it's is also standards around customer authentication and the data payload that needs to get passed from merchant back to issuer to ensure the customer is who they say they are and to give us better odds of authenticating that individual. And it's also a set of standards around securing the payload, the transaction itself, what data goes in there and how it's secured by an EMVco cryptographic standards. So it's all 3 pieces coming together, and we're excited about it. We're hopeful that we can get to work in converting our own experience. Visa Checkout, over to it a little bit later this year. We'll see when the detailed specs come out from the EMVco.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: Is that the next milestone, the EMVco specs?

JACK FORESTELL: Yes.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: And those are expected when?

JACK FORESTELL: Hopefully, late summer, fall.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: Okay. Okay. So if we kind of fast forward to this future state where you've got the specs, and then go through the process of coding to the specs, does the Visa Checkout brand that we've been accustomed to seeing in the online world, does that brand continue to survive? Or does that brand itself change in terms of what the consumer sees behind a unified payment button, which I guess would initiate the online checkout? I'm just trying to kind of envision the consumer experience.

JACK FORESTELL: Yes, Well, first of all, with respect to exactly how the common experience will show up in the beginning, no decisions have been made, no specs have been published. So I can't tell you exactly how, who's brand will show up in exact ways at the beginning of it. What I will say though is, look, as we've worked with partners in the payment facilitation space, acquirers, gateways, merchants, we find that our partners love the Visa brand, intend to, want to showcase it prominently throughout the payments experience, whether it's at the beginning, in the middle or at the end. Because it represents back to the consumer exactly what I talked about at the very beginning of this, which is safe, secure, fast, reliable and that we've got your back. And so I fully expect that you should see the Visa brand interwoven through transactions on a common button as much or more than you did through a single button.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: What have you heard so far from merchants? Obviously, they're a key constituency in all of this. I think initially maybe, there was a press release from one of the merchant organizations saying, "Hey, look, we want to make sure we're involved and we have input into the standards," et cetera. I mean, do you see that as a significant stumbling block to get all this done? Or has there been some initial partnering there involving the merchants?

JACK FORESTELL: Look, we want input and collaboration from everyone, including merchants. So we absolutely want merchant feedback. We have consulted with our merchant partners throughout the course of this. I'd say, the general consensus is optimism around the ease and convenience of integrating to a single button with the common experience that consumers are going to be able to intuitively understand. But if I were a merchant, I'd say, "Hey, it sounds like a great plan." Let me wait and see when the specs come out and I'll do my integration and we'll see what happens.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: And I guess the idea would be that this would be easier for merchants, right? Because instead 6 different button providers coming to them and saying, "Code to us, code to us, code to us," you essentially code to one standard and then I guess the merchant can decide which specific buttons, if you will, they wanted to have available underneath the single button, or something to that effect.

JACK FORESTELL: That's exactly right.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: Okay, okay. So we look forward to that. On a related topic, let's talk a little bit about W3C standards. And maybe you can just level set from the audience by talking about what W3C is as kind of a standards body, because I think there's some awareness but not full understanding in the marketplace. And then how that dovetails with some industry announcements we've seen recently from the likes of Google. And we'll probably have a couple of questions underneath that thought.

JACK FORESTELL: Yes, sure. So to start, W3C is the standards body that sets standards for web browsers. They've recently developed a set of APIs for payments, a set of API standards. Payment request is kind of the core standards. And the intent of it, just to keep it simple, is to make it easy for merchants to integrate payments from a browser into their website. Our view is -- and probably predictable by now as we've been talking. But look, it's an open standard. It's meant to make things easier for merchants. At this point in history, the payments that sit in the back end of that standard are card network payments, so things that make it easier and faster for more digital commerce to happen. And they get people a path to card-based payments. We're fans of those open standards. Now we've been developing the SRC standards in parallel, but separately from the W3C standards. The SRC standards I just described go beyond browser and are applicable to all digital payments. And as I said, they cover not only the user experience piece, but also the authentication and the tokenization pieces. So there's still a lot of work left to do, but I'm hopeful that we can see a dovetailing of those 2 standards, and that eventually, a W3C payment request can incorporate the SRC standards into it.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: Questions from the audience for Jack? Can we get a microphone up here and then one in the middle, please, as well?

COLIN R. DUCHARME, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR OF EQUITY OPPORTUNITIES & SENIOR EQUITY ANALYST, STERLING CAPITAL MANAGEMENT LLC: Colin Ducharme with Sterling Capital. Regarding the B2B market, the networks have talked a lot about the opportunity there. Al Kelly has mentioned the travel and procurement probably, the easier wins, and I would view those as kind of the card-able opportunities, B2B payment types. But just curious in your role as head of products for the noncarded payment types, what sorts of product strategies is Visa bringing to market to attack that opportunity? And then from the outside looking in, how can we kind of measure the success in the near term?

JACK FORESTELL: Yes. Look, there's -- I don't want to dismiss the card-able space. There's still a lot of runway left there and a lot of opportunity for us in verticals like the ones you mentioned to drive more volume. If you look at the overall opportunity, the noncard-able piece of B2B payments is obviously a much more significant piece of what happens. That said, a lot of those are very large institution-to-institution payments. So somewhere in the middle where you get to sort of medium-sized enterprise business-to-business payments, that's, I think, the sweet spot that we're going after. And there, we're developing straight-through processing solutions. We're leveraging much of the same backbone technology as Visa Direct to be able to initiate -- enable businesses to initiate push payments from one business to another business. We're starting with use cases like insurance, is an easy one where we can offer a service for insurance companies to make disbursements to claimants or other partners via the straight through processing service. Look, it's still early days so I'm not sure what to tell you in terms of, like, how you are going to be able to check on our progress on it. It's probably not something that we're going to hang out a shingle on just yet, but stay tuned.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Similar topic -- or same topic. You think back, I think it was 2009, '10, you guys did a partnership with Syncada, USB. What is it, as you see at the bottleneck that's kind of preventing B2B from taking off faster? I would have thought given the lack of penetration, by now, there'd be more growth. And I'm just curious how you see the bottlenecks there and what you can do to push those aside?

JACK FORESTELL: Look, it's a complicated space. The fluidity of change when you're talking about institution-to-institution type payments as opposed to when you're talking about the world of consumer and digital, and digital platforms, the pace is just different. The inertia is different. And so while we as consumers can switch our behavior to operating via a mobile device and clicking, collecting our coffee and paying for it digitally whereas we wouldn't have imagined that a few years ago. When I'm operating the AR or the AP function inside of a company and I've got it wired up with an ERP platform and I've got those connections premade with wire and check and I've got a treasury with someone, there's just a lot of work to do to close the sale. And then there's a lot of work to do after that to get the change happening. So it's a lot more trench warfare that just scales less quickly than what we see as digital sort of seeps the consumer space.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: Other questions? Let me just ask you one follow-on that. I mean, I guess, we've always thought that part of the challenge in B2B is trying to make kind of the traditional interchange model really transfer over. I mean, is that a genuine challenge? I mean, maybe I'm oversimplifying it, but if I think about, just take the average kind of small business, if you will, and I'm buying $50,000 worth of equipment from another small business, I don't want to pay $500 to complete that transaction. Is that an oversimplistic way of looking at it? Or is that part of the inherent challenge here of how do you find kind of a happy medium between, like, checks or a slow ACH versus what we might be able to offer in the future?

JACK FORESTELL: Yes, look, it's a component of it. But in my experience, having tested a lot of solutions in the space, solving that problem by itself does not -- is not adequate. You've got to get to the core of all of the other pieces. You've got to make it easy to have the payment service integrated into whether you're a large enterprise and you've got an ERP platform, or whether you're a small restaurant and you have an ERP platform that's designed specifically for you. The integration has to happen into those platforms. It's got to be simple. You've got to be able to understand it. You've got to have counterparties on the other side that can take the payments. So there's a lot of complexity to get through beyond just the pricing piece, which is a component of it, but frankly, that's probably a little easier to solve than some of the other parts.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: We continue to get asked a lot about the broader competitive landscape in payments and perhaps sort of nontraditional competitors. Amazon is certainly one that always is fun to talk about and no shortage of headlines there. Relatively recently, some talk about maybe a checking account-like product coming from them, detail's a little bit sketchy. But would just love your perspective since you kind of see everything in the ecosystem. What do you think perhaps their endgame in payments may be? What do you think about kind of what they've done so far? Obviously, they've got an online checkout button. They've got some actual card products, private label and co-brand. So would just love your perspective on how you think they may be viewing their longer-term role in payments? Are they more kind of an enabler, a disrupter?

JACK FORESTELL: You got a lot of -- a lot packed in there, Jason.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: Yes, exactly. Well, it's not an earnings call. I get to ask all the questions.

JACK FORESTELL: First, the Amazon. They're a great partner. I think Amazon and Visa have an incredibly symbiotic relationship. Amazon has done a lot for the growth of digital payments globally. And I think Visa and card networks have done a lot for Amazon in enabling a simple, friction-free experience for them as they have driven that growth. So it's yin and yang, it works well, and we're huge fans of Amazon. With respect to Amazon's aspirations in banking and payments, look, I read the same things you read. So it's probably a question that's better posed to the Amazon team. But look, here's I guess how I'd take a run at that one is if -- we've seen other non-FI players enter the banking space to varying degrees of success over the years. If I were a non-FI player looking at getting into the space, I think I'd probably be looking at trying to find the partnership assets out there that give me the best chance of creating the best product and the best customer experience that I could create. And I'd say beyond being a great tech company, Amazon is a great customer experience company. I think if I were in those shoes, I'd be looking at partnerships with banks. I'd be looking at partnerships with payment networks. If I want to offer a card product to my consumers, I want to offer them the one they want. And I say this to our co-brand partners all the time, "Look, if you want offer your consumers a payment vehicle that they want, don't listen to me. Go ask them and watch what they do. Your customers want a Visa card." So we'll see if the rumors are true, if any of that plays out. But that's how I would think about it if I were sitting on the other side.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: What about private label, more broadly? I mean, private-label cards have been around forever, I think, longer than Visa cards, actually. But clearly, more and more different types of merchants seem to be promoting their own types of private-label cards. And again, Amazon is one of those as well for their Prime consumers. And the Target REDcard, another example, I guess. I mean, has Visa changed its view at all in terms of just kind of competitive threat from these products? Because it seems like maybe the value proposition that they're trying to offer consumers is maybe a little bit richer, at least in some cases, than it's been in the past. Would you agree with that premise or...

JACK FORESTELL: Look, you mentioned it, private-label cards have been around for a very, very long time. So I haven't seen any abrupt changes in the relative share of open-loop and network-based cards relative to private-label in the last decade or so. And so look, I think, private-label cards play a role. They will be around for a really long time. As you mentioned, there are merchant partners out there who emphasized them. They use them as a platform to deliver value back to their consumers in ways that they can't or don't through other vehicles. And that's great. Again, more things that draw consumers into digital payments, that draw consumers into network payments, that displace cash, that habituate consumers to using electronic and digital payments, all good with us. I like our chances at being competitive with private-label given the value-added services we have and the 46 million outlets where you can use a Visa card relative to a private-label card.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: Right, right. It's a strong value proposition. And I guess, that sort of begs the bigger picture question, which is the competitive moat that everyone always talks about with Visa and with Mastercard as well. What really does keep you guys up at night when you think about out-of-the-box types of scenarios where the traditional networks could get "disrupted?" What really worries you longer term in theory, and how do you try and stay one step ahead?

JACK FORESTELL: Look, we've got an incredibly resilient business model. It's really stood the test of time and it's supported by really strong secular growth. We also have kind of what I think as somewhat of a strategic runway where we can see developments across the industry, across the world. And we have the time to react to them. Lot -- we get asked a lot about, what about Alipay, what about WeChat? Are those models going to come to a market near you anytime soon? I won't get into a long discourse about that, but look, there's a set of circumstances that emerged in China that are incredibly unique. We are starting to see those players spill outside of China, but we've had time to develop our own competitive response. We're building out the push payment service. We're building out QR code standards. And we're starting to enable those standards in emerging markets in the regions where those competitors are spilling out. The keeping up at night one is probably just a little bit more around the pace of regulatory change around the world. And again, we invest significantly to partner with governments around the world to keep governments informed, to partner with governments. But there can always be a little bit more unpredictability when it comes to the regulatory side of things. And that's -- that one makes it a little harder to react to.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: When you think about product strategy taking, let's just say, a 3- to 5-year view out, and you think about the classic sort of buy versus build decisions, I mean, it feels like, obviously, putting Visa Europe on the side, Visa has not been very acquisitive in recent years. There was a period post-IPO where there was a decent pace of M&A. And then it seems like we've transitioned more towards more the build versus the buy. Where are we now? Are we pretty comfortable with this sort of organic reinvestment? Or might we see some resurgence of acquisition activity?

JACK FORESTELL: Yes, I think we are pretty comfortable. And look, I'll give you the product guy answer to your question. When a look at it, I love our core platform. I want that to be the highest-performing, safest, most secure platform in the world. I think we're good at that. I also wanted to have the most feature-rich set of services to enable partners and developers to come on to our platform and build new solutions. That's where I'd say, look, we're building new services at a breakneck pace, but we're under no illusion that we're the only ones in the world who have good enough ideas to attach to our own platform. So we're very much in the market to add products and service on to the platform through acquisition. Obviously, we've been very diligent in the way we think that through and what we do there. So it's probably a balance.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: How are you preparing for Internet of Things? It seems like Visa and others in the payments space should certainly have a play there, right, just with all the connected devices that are coming down the pike. But how much of a focus is it that internally? I mean, do you have a dedicated team underneath you that just thinks about IoT? Or how do you address the opportunity?

JACK FORESTELL: Yes, look, IoT is just nothing but goodness as far as I'm concerned. In fact, look, when a payment moves from physical space to digital space, our sort of share of transaction volume almost doubles. And IoT is sort of a vehicle for fueling an explosion in the endpoints that can take a payment. The way we think about it though it is more like these are hardware devices that are going to be sitting everywhere around the world. What really powers the hardware devices though is software. And so our job, as we see it, is to ensure that is easy to integrate Visa payment services into the software that runs on those IoT devices. So we're working hard to ensure that we're easy to get integrated into voice-based AI platforms that are going to power a ton of IoT devices, that were easy to integrate into connected car platforms, that were easy to integrate into basic card on file using the SRC platform that I described. If you want to make a payment on the scooter that you rode here today or on the bike, it's going to be a card on file payment that's delivered by an SRC experience. So there are some use cases when you get into certain types of IoT, like wearables, where you might want to make a transaction happen at the physical point of sale. That's where we have to interact with the hardware with a program called Visa Ready that we've built out to enable smaller players in the wearable space to be able to quickly on board and connect payments to those kind of devices. So we're absolutely excited about it, thinking about it, and we have a team of people working on it.

JASON ALAN KUPFERBERG: Terrific. I think we're going to leave it there. Thank you very much.

JACK FORESTELL: All right. Thank you. Thanks, Jason. I appreciate it.

urn:contentItem:5VF7-BSC1-JB20-G4GX-00000-00Visa Inc at Goldman Sachs Technology & Internet Conference - Final2019-02-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:12ZLexisNexis021319a12285526.726Visa Incat Goldman SachsTechnology & Internet Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Ryan M. McInerney

Visa Inc.- President

Conference Call Participants

* James Edward Schneider

Goldman Sachs GroupInc., Research Division - VP

Presentation

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER, VP, GOLDMAN SACHS GROUPINC., RESEARCH DIVISION: Okay. Excellent. Okay. Welcome everybody to our lunchtime keynote presentation of the Goldman SachsTechnology and Internet Conference. My name is Jim Schneider. I cover the payments space here at Goldman on the research side. And it's my pleasure to introduce Visa and the President of Visa, Ryan McInerney.

Welcome back, Ryan. Thanks for being here.

RYAN M. MCINERNEY, PRESIDENT, VISA INC.: Thanks for having me.

Questions and Answers

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: You've been the president of Visa for about 6 years now. Maybe just start off on a very, very broad strategic level. When you look back at what the company has achieved over the past 6 years, what's the top thing that you think has been transformational to the company's success? And what's that going to be 10 years from now?

RYAN M. MCINERNEY: I think the thing that we've accomplished that's going to have the biggest impact 10 years from now has been -- is the opening up of our network. If you go back in time 10 years ago, Visa was a closed architecture technology platform that largely distributed debit card, credit card products to clients. What we've been working on over the past 6 years has been to fundamentally change that, to open up our network and make it a commerce platform that anyone on the seller side of the ecosystem or the buyer side of the ecosystem can innovate on and build products on. Part of it's been about opening up our technology platform, VisaNet, and taking all of the services that we enable inside of VisaNet and turning those into easy-to-consume APIs that can be accessed by developers anywhere around the world. But more so it's been about opening up the ecosystem and enabling a lot of the different players that are innovating and delivering new commerce experiences to use our network as a commerce platform. And it's changed our business in significant ways. And I think it's changed how commerce is working around the world in ways that we're still seeing great examples of. And what happens is when we open up the network, we find that there's lots and lots of people around the world that are able to innovate with our APIs and our services in ways that we never would've thought of. They're able to take what we delivered as a merchant API to create better information for issuers on transactions and turn it into a data stream that prefills applications for small businesses when they apply for loans and take our alerts API and turn it into a way to provide digital receipts and so on and so forth, creating much richer and better commerce experiences.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: That's great. And then maybe if you think more short term over the next year, what are the top 2 or 3 strategic priorities for the company?

RYAN M. MCINERNEY: So one is Europe. I mean, Europe is an enormous opportunity for us, now we're having the privilege to own the Visa Europe franchise. We just see significant opportunities in Europe. But putting Europe aside and talking more broadly about the company around the world, 3 sets of things that we're very, very focused on. One is expanding our client base, expanding the partners that we do business with, working with new FinTech players that are innovating on the buyer experiences and the buyer side of the equation, working with new B2B players in terms of creating different business models and value propositions that can simplify and streamline B2B payments and ultimately drive a significant volume over our network. I was just meeting with Flint Lane, who's probably in the room because we were just meeting together. Billtrust is a great partner of ours where we've just launched what's really going to be a revolutionary way, we think, for B2B payments to happen, in the business payments network. And that's an example of expanding our partner and client base. That's one. The second priority for us is -- it's about capturing new flows. We have this great network that we've built over many, many years. It's got scale. It's got broad-based acceptance. And what we're finding is creating new use cases, new products, new relationships, new partners -- new partnerships is able to -- we're able to create lots of new flows over the network. B2B is an example that I just mentioned. Push Payments and our Visa Direct product, which, if you want to talk about it, we can talk about as another example. And then the third priority for us at Visa is about continuing to expand the products, the solutions and the services that we deliver to our partners and our clients that help them run their business better. We have a whole series of businesses and teams that come into work every day and they're focused on how can they help our clients and our partners do more effective commerce. We have a rich suite of risk solutions. For example, we have a Visa Advanced Authorization product that helps issuers score transactions in real time with over 500 pieces of data every second all around the world. We also have a Decision Manager Product that helps sellers determine whether or not a transaction is risky or not and hopefully, authorize more transactions. We have a great set of loyalty products. I rode over here in an Uber today because it's pouring out as you know and actually paid for the ride using points that I'd accumulated from a rewards program that we designed and a loyalty platform that we built for Uber, called Visa Local Offers that allows me to earn Uber points every time I spend money at merchants and sellers all around San Francisco. We have big businesses focused on acceptance. CyberSource, which is the largest gateway provider in the world that's helping e-commerce merchants really deliver their entire value proposition all around the world. We have an issuer processing business, one of the biggest issuer processing platforms called Visa DPS that helps our issuing clients do everything from send out electronic statements to answer the phones and everything in between. We also have a great set of data solutions. We're working with issuers and sellers all around the world on all types of different ways to enhance their businesses and their -- kind of intelligence of how they run their business. And then finally, we have teams of consultants and data analysts as part of our Visa Consulting and Analytics business in countries all around the world, working hand-in-hand with our clients to help them with all of the different various aspects of their business that they run every day. So a third priority of continuing to expand all of the different product solutions and services that we deliver is a really important priority for us. But in large part, it's important because it helps our clients do what they do better.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Yes. And there's a lot of exciting issues there. I do want to also focus on the consumer for a second because clearly, as we all know, consumer growth on the payments side has been -- this is the strongest it's been in years over the past year and you're in a very well positioned place to look at all those transactions on a real time basis. I think your guidance and outlook for payments volume growth this year is in the low double-digit range and that's despite the fact that you're lapping some pretty difficult comps. So can you kind of give us some color about, globally, what you see in terms of the regions, the corridors and spending trends and what's happening?

RYAN M. MCINERNEY: Yes. I think just kind of from a macro point of view, the spending trends continue to be reasonably robust around the world. In this last quarter, we saw acceleration in spending in the CEMEA region, in the Asia-Pacific region, if you exclude China, as well as in Latin America. Looking at the rest of the world, we saw some slight deceleration in Europe, in Canada and United States. And if you look, kind of if you equalize it for Visa-specific factors, it was kind of about a point plus or minus in those markets, but still at reasonably strong levels. I'd also say we had a reasonably good holiday season both in the U.S. and in other markets around the world. In the U.S., again, if you just kind of normalize out all of the Visa factors and focus really on Americans and how did their spending look during November and December in this country, it was about the same as it was last year, about 8%, which is really good growth. We have seen some changes in consumer behavior that we're keeping an eye on. One is, which will be no surprise to this group, but e-commerce just continues to -- I mean, the way we are all spending is massively changing and it is more and more and more online and on mobile devices. And the growth in e-commerce during the holiday season continued to be very, very strong. We're also seeing in the U.S. some shift in behavior towards debit or at least we did during the holiday season and some very robust growth in debit card spending in the U.S. And then finally, we saw some deceleration in the last couple of weeks of December in the U.S. We saw a rebound in January. I mean there was a lot going on as everybody in this room knows well, in the last couple of weeks of December. It definitely showed up in consumer spending. There's no doubt about it. But we've seen a nice rebound back in January.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: That's really interesting color. And so maybe cross border for a second. That's a very important financial driver for Visa. You've been able to make sustained double-digit growth there over the past year that decelerated a little bit to 9% last quarter and then that slipped again to 6% in January, I believe. Can you maybe help us understand some of the dynamics here? How much of it's just strong dollar causing that weakness? How much is other factors? And kind of were you -- what factors are you really keeping close eye on as you look forward prospectively as what that's going to do?

RYAN M. MCINERNEY: Yes. I'll take the last part of your question, in terms of what it's going to do. I think it's too early to tell. But we've definitely seen some deceleration in cross-border spending around the world. The strengthening of the dollar has been a big factor. We've seen slowing growth of spending from inbound corridors of consumer spending into the United States. We've seen some deceleration from Asia, from Europe, from Canada, from Mexico, all big corridors into the U.S. Our cross-border business over time, which we have a lot of experience with, it'll go up and down as the strength of the dollar changes. The reverse of that, we've actually seen some good spending from all of us, outbound spending outside of the United States. But the relative size of those businesses is very, very different. Our inbound cross-border business is much bigger, just given the fact that the U.S. is a big travel destination for many people, but also is where many of the biggest e-commerce companies are based. So we're keeping a very close eye on it. We have seen some deceleration in other corridors around the world, but that inbound into the U.S. has been the biggest one. And as I said at the beginning, we're watching the data carefully. We're looking at all the corridors, all the spending by seller segment, by issuer, all those types of things. But too early to tell what's going to happen.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Yes. Now you've alluded to e-commerce before. Obviously, everybody here at this conference is focused on it. I believe you mentioned on the earnings call that over the holiday, it was 1/3 of your U.S. consumer spending growing more than 3x faster than all the other spend. What are the big things that investors should keep in mind about the importance of e-commerce to Visa? And what that means in terms of either spreads, ancillary revenues? And just overall, how much of it is a tailwind to you versus a headwind?

RYAN M. MCINERNEY: Well, the first thing I'd say about e-commerce is, it's a great time to be a consumer. I mean, just think about it. It's a great time to be a consumer, order online, pick up in store, order ahead, mobile commerce, tap-to-pay. Like all these different types of experiences making it much, much easier for all of us to buy and hopefully you're buying using your Visa cards. It's a very -- it's a great time to be a consumer. And e-commerce is in part what's fueling that. E-commerce is great for consumers. It's also -- it's great for Visa. When you look at kind of just the share -- our share of transactions at check out, it's about twice what it is in the physical world. So as every dollar moves from physical face-to-face spending and moves online, our share of those transactions goes up 2x, which is obviously very good for our business and good for our clients. But even beyond that, e-commerce creates all kinds of opportunity for us to help sellers and to help issuers, help them reduce fraud and increase authorizations, help them deliver all the different types of experiences I talked about, order ahead, mobile commerce, all the different pays, those different types of things. The business units that I mentioned earlier, all spend an enormous amount of resources trying to help issuers and sellers deliver great commerce experiences to all of us. And that creates an opportunity for to help our clients, but also creates a number of different revenue streams for us. So as the transaction moves from the physical world to the online world, not only do we get more than our fair share of physical payments, we also create lots of new opportunities to help clients and, therefore, create new streams of revenue.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Great. And then relative to e-commerce for Visa, you and other industry partners are looking to establish this idea of a common industry button for merchant websites. Can you maybe talk about why that's necessary? Why or why not it might be more successful from some of the past efforts? And what your idea of success looks like in, say, a couple of years?

RYAN M. MCINERNEY: The short answer of why we're focused on it is for all the good things I just talked about with e-commerce, in many situations, it's just still harder than it should be. A large portion of e-commerce for all of us is what we call card on file commerce. It's pretty simple. It's pretty frictionless. It's often invisible. It's a great experience. But in the U.S. and in many markets around the world, a reasonably large portion of e-commerce transactions are, what we often call, guest checkout. The experience varies based on kind of which online retailer you're buying from, but it's nowhere near as simple and easy as it should be. You're often filling out your name, your address, your 16-digit account number so on and so forth. So it's that part of the e-commerce buying experience that we're focused on with its secure remote commerce initiative. And part of it is, as you described, kind of creating what people often call is the button, but it's much more than the button. It's creating a simple, frictionless user experience where if you compare it to that guest checkout experience today, it's much, much, much better and getting close to that invisible experience that I just described. But even beyond the consumer experience, we're focused in the SRC, the Secure Remote Commerce initiative on making it safer for consumers and making it easier for both sellers and issuers to authenticate and authorize the transactions. So the technology that underlies the Secure Remote Commerce initiative is the token technology, the EMVco token technology specs. And what that technology allows merchants and issuers to do is have a lot more confidence that when Ryan is buying something at a SRC-enabled merchant, they know who Ryan is, they are able to authorize my transactions at a much, much higher rate. Their sales go up. The issuer's client is happier and has a much better customer experience and they're getting more transactions. So we're very excited about the initiative. We think it'll make commerce easier, simpler, safer and allow us to all have more of our transactions authorized. You alluded to this, there's been a lot of attempts both by us and others over the course of the last many years to accomplish these types of objectives. We feel good about what we tried. I mean, innovation is about continuing to try lots of new things, not getting stuck on what you've done, being willing to look to new alternatives, new ideas, test new things. And we hope this is going to allow us to make real good progress and making it easier for all of us to buy things online.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Yes. Going back to Europe. You mentioned that is a strategic priority a minute ago. You've owned Visa Europe for almost 3 years now. Obviously, a landmark transaction for the company. Maybe can you lay out for us what you see as the market opportunity in Europe over the next 5 years? And what the definition of success looks there -- looks like there as well?

RYAN M. MCINERNEY: We're very excited about the opportunities in Europe. I think the opportunities for Visa are very, very significant in Europe. Just to check in on where we are, we have been going through a technology migration in Europe to bring both Visa Europe and all of our clients and partners onto a global VisaNet technology platform, the one that I was talking about earlier. We completed that migration in September. So starting in September, all of our clients in Europe, whether they be acquirers or sellers or issuers, they're now on our global platform. What that gives us the ability to do is to deliver a lot of the solutions, the products and services that I was mentioning earlier to clients in Europe that previously had no access to them. Take the risk solutions that I mentioned earlier. We just started bringing new issuers online using the Visa Advanced Authorization scoring solution that I mentioned earlier. I think we have just 60 issuers up and running now on it. Just those 60 issuers, for when they started using that solution -- these are big sophisticated banks in Europe. Their frauds come down 6%. That's a significant improvement in fraud. And our sales teams and client teams are working with all of our issuers across Europe to bring them all up online on that risk solution. And the same thing's happening in all 6 of the different business units that I mentioned earlier. So one opportunity is helping our clients perform better, generating revenue from that as part of it. But moving beyond that, we feel now that we're really operating as one company. We have all of our clients on one global platform. We have a significant opportunity in credit, which is a product where I think we have -- we've under penetrated the market opportunity relative to our capabilities, certainly, in other markets, we're very focused on how we expand there. There are several markets where we think we have an opportunity to grow our market share overall. Commercial is a huge opportunity for us in Europe. Previously, if you go back several years when large issuers and even large corporates were making decisions about who their partners would be in the commercial space, we weren't able to bring them an integrated solution. We could go in a coordinated way with Visa Europe, but it was 2 companies, it was 2 solutions. We had to try to coordinate our best. We did the best we could, but nowhere as well as we could compete. And the last thing I mentioned on Europe is there's a lot of innovation happening with FinTechs in Europe. And for reasons that might be obvious, the Visa Europe association, which was owned by the banks a couple of years ago, they just weren't as focused on how you could enable a lot of the FinTech players in Europe to do the things that they're doing. We're very, very focused on it. So we've been having great success. We've had some big wins over the course of the last 6, 9 months in the FinTech space in Europe, and we're very focused on how do we continue to help those FinTechs create great consumer products, great consumer experiences and do it on the Visa platform.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Yes. And then relative to Europe, the regulatory environment has been shifting a little bit over the past several years. Maybe talk about the impact of those regulatory changes on electronic payments volume growth in Europe? And then specifically address what's the impact of the more recent cross-border interchange rules on your business heading into Europe?

RYAN M. MCINERNEY: There's been a lot of regulatory activity in Europe in payments. No question about it. I think it's too early to tell what's going to happen. As it relates to the first part of your question, this has been a whole series of regulations that have happened to interchange, the PSD2 regulations, so on and so forth. We're very focused on working with our clients in Europe to help them create products and businesses that are going to thrive in a lower interchange environment and what's going to be a much more open banking environment going forward. The PSD2 regulations, for example, have a whole bunch of provisions as it relates to Secure Customer Authentication. We're working with e-commerce players, big and small, we're working with issuers, big and small on how they can comply with the new regulations, use a series of solutions that Visa has developed to enable the consumers to have the same frictionless experiences that they've come to know and love. We're also working with a lot of our bank partners on how they can take advantage of the open banking provisions in the PSD2 regulations to create better experiences for their overall financial relationship as it relates to their clients. So it's creating a lot of different opportunities. I think the competitive playing field is going to continue to be very, very dynamic in Europe. There's going to be a lot of players that I think will be able to thrive and win share and strengthen their customer relationship as part of it. There's others that won't do as well and we want to do everything we can to work with our clients to help them succeed.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Yes. That's good to see. And then maybe I want to move to contactless payments for a second. I think that's -- it's fair to say that that's something that's done much better internationally outside the U.S. than here in the U.S. I think you previously said that outside the U.S., face-to-face penetration of contactless is 44%. But it seems like there's finally some needle-moving activities here in country. I think over 70 of the top 100 merchants are now accepting it and now we've seen Chase, Wells Fargo, Bank of America all announcing that they would be rolling out contactless physical credit and debit cards over the next year or so. Do you think we're finally at an inflection point here in terms of the adoption in the U.S.? And what does it all mean from Visa -- for Visa from an economics and growth perspective?

RYAN M. MCINERNEY: Can I start with a quick survey? I'm just curious. I'm just curious, for everybody in the room, raise your hand if you have a credit or debit card that's enabled for tap-to-pay contactless payments?

(Voting)

RYAN M. MCINERNEY: Raise them up high. That's pretty good. I'm just wondering, if we would have done this a year ago, what we would have seen. That's good. That's better than I expected. Thank you. Let me start outside the U.S. then come to the U.S. Outside the U.S., tapping to pay is increasingly becoming the default way people pay. As you said, we've got more than 4 out of every 10 transactions happening around the world are people tapping to pay. It's a significant statistic. And if you look in like Australia as the extreme, they're more than 90%, almost every Visa transaction -- face-to-face transaction that happens in Australia is tap-to-pay. And Poland is a great example. Poland, pretty soon every merchant acceptance point in Poland will be enabled for contactless. 100%. So outside the U.S., this is becoming the way people pay with Visa. And consumers love it. It's faster. It's quicker. It's easier. Sellers love it. They're able to move people through the lines more quickly. Their customers are happier. So we feel really, really good about what's happening with tap-to-pay all around the world. So now you come to the United States. I think we're doing really, really good work in the United States. The good news of having led the efforts in all these different countries around the world is we know what the adoption curve looks like. We know how consumer behavior changes. We know once that you've laid the groundwork, what can happen. And we're not at an inflection point yet, but we will be soon. In the United States, 60% of all Visa transactions, all Visa face-to-face transactions, are happening at terminals that are enabled for tap-to-pay. That in most markets is the hardest thing to get done. So the groundwork has been laid on the seller side of the ecosystem. And as you alluded to, U.S. issuers -- and you all said when you raised your hands, U.S. issuers are starting to issue the cards. We expect to have 100 million Visa tap-to-pay cards issued in the United States by the end of the year. So I feel really good and I'm very optimistic that all of us in this room are going to be able to have the great buying experience that other Visa customers all around the world are starting to have. And I really think, as we move through that, people are going to be very, very impressed with just how the buying experience works.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Yes. Yes. That's good to see. And you've talked about a lot of new Visa capabilities. You referred to Visa Direct earlier, which is essentially running your network in reverse, effectively, in order to accommodate things like Push Payments for peer-to-peer applications as well as things like companies paying insurance claims, payroll, Uber drivers, et cetera. So I believe you disclosed now that Visa Direct is now at $100 billion volume run rate growing at 100%, which is a big number. So how do you think how big this opportunity could be over time from both a volume and revenue perspective for the company?

RYAN M. MCINERNEY: We think it's an enormous opportunity. Visa Direct is a great example of innovation at Visa as you alluded to in terms of reversing the transaction. One of our product engineers had an idea a few years ago. And the idea was, what if we took a transaction on our network and just ran it in reverse. And the product scrum team started to work on it and they came up with a way to operationalize. And at the time, we had no idea how commercially viable it could and it would be. As you mentioned, the growth of the product in just a couple years has been very significant. But I think what's so exciting to us is 2 things. First, as we are out there on the front lines talking to partners and clients in countries all around the world, what we're finding is Visa Direct compared to Fast ACH or real-time payments or what have you is very, very different. And the differences and all of the value-added capabilities built into Visa Direct enable our partners to do things they just can't do with RTP or Fast ACH. ACH, Fast ACH in many countries around the world doesn't have the ability to preauthorize. It doesn't run 24/7 365 in most countries, our country included. Visa Direct allows you to reach beyond just a bank account to reach credit cards and prepaid cards. So the reach is stronger. It's live and up and running in 150 countries around the world today, 70 of which are Fast Funds enabled for near instant payments. We also hear from consumers because they just love the fact that I don't have to give out my bank account information. I can just make a transaction the same way that I always have with a Visa product. And it's enabled for cross border. So compared to some of the alternatives out there, we're finding that it's a rich set of capabilities that people really value. And as you alluded to, the use cases are kind of mushroomed and exploding. I feel like it's almost every day that our Visa Direct team is coming into my office with a new use case that they're finding for it. It's payroll, it's bill pay, it's gaming, it's disbursements, it's marketplace payouts. The list kind of goes on and on, and I wish we could have said we laid out a strategy in all these different verticals and segments and we're going to go attack it. What's really happening is we're learning as we go that there's just all these different use cases in all these different segments around the world where people really want a richer transaction and a transaction that has the type of capabilities that Visa Direct has. So we're very excited about it. How big it could be? We don't know. But we're very optimistic about the growth and what's ahead of us.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Since you've come onboard, Ryan, I think Visa as a company has spent a lot more time working with merchants more than the company had previously. And I guess, over the past year, I think you cited the number of merchants where Visa was accepted was up 15% to about 54 million. I think it's a pretty shocking number for most people, given the scale of -- and maturity of your business. Certainly, it was for me. Maybe can you give us a sense of where all these merchants are coming from? Is it emerging market merchants? Is it small merchants in the U.S.? And where do you think that number can go over time?

RYAN M. MCINERNEY: Don't tell our sales teams that it's shocking because I think they have a lot more work to do. And seriously, we're very proud of the growth on the seller side of the ecosystem. 15% growth year-over-year is good, but we have a lot more work to do. We just think there's so much opportunity ahead of us all around the world. But to answer your question, it's coming in developed markets and it's coming in developing markets. In the developed markets, it's things like tap-to-pay and contactless. We're seeing expansion into vending, in parking, in all the different areas where we all see people or would use cash ourselves. And we're also seeing great penetration in new segments like B2B, like bill pay, like rent payments, so on and so forth. So it's very much a developed market story. But the numbers are really significant in the developing world. And here what you're seeing is a couple things that are happening at the same time. First is expansion of reliable connectivity. The second is drastic reductions in the price of acceptance terminals themselves and in many parts of the world, skipping the need to even have acceptance devices at all. We've -- in the spirit of opening up our network to what we were talking about earlier, we enabled people in India, for example, to pay with QR codes using a Visa credential. I think we're about to pass or we just passed 1 million acceptance locations just in India using QR. We have great teams all around the world working to turn the antenna on a phone that many people have seen with Apple Pay and Google Pay and others as a way to pay, but now turning that antenna around as a way to accept payment, so that we could have phone-to-phone payments and so on and so forth. So the expansion in the seller side of the ecosystem, it's been very good work over the last couple of years. But we see it -- we want to see a lot more expansion both in the developed markets and the developing markets.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Great. B2B payments. I think that's an area where you have talked a lot more about recently. I think you have been talking about the fact that B2B is 11% of your overall volume. A lot of that's on kind of corporate payments and traveling expenses and entertainment expenses and things like that. Those have been a bit of a stubborn market in terms of going digital, a lot of that's still on paper check. So if you think about the market opportunity in B2B and what's kind of required to make it digital, what are some of the barriers and obstacles that need to be overcome? And kind of maybe think about what the size of that opportunity could be for Visa over time?

RYAN M. MCINERNEY: Yes. It has been stubborn. It's been very stubborn, but we're committed to cracking it. And a lot of what that's going to take is partnerships. But let me back up and talk about B2B more broadly. First, while -- and I acknowledge a big part of our business is commercial cards, P-Card, T&E and all of that today, I think about 10% of our business is -- 11% of our business is now B2B around the world. In many markets around the world, although it sounds mundane to us, that is like massive innovation. Big developed markets that you all would think about as highly sophisticated payment markets, the ecosystem hasn't evolved in such a way there where what are basic products here, they don't exist. So we have great opportunity in many markets around the world to continue to expand our B2B business just on the bread and butter commercial card, small business card, P-Card, T&E card, those type of things. Second area that we're very excited about is virtual cards. Virtual cards enable us to create lots of new use cases for our partners all around the world. We've been really focused with our client teams here in the U.S. and around the world at expanding the footprint of that business for us. We've announced some great new wins and some great new partnerships, WEX, Ixaris and others over the course of the last many months. And we expect to continue to grow our share of that business. But then back to the stubborn point and where partnerships come in. If you want to talk about the trillions, the tens of trillions, the many tens of trillion dollars of B2B payments that exist around the world today, we think cracking that's going to require really new business models that are going to allow us to simplify how those payments work and bring together what can be a very fragmented ecosystem today. I mentioned the work we're doing to build trust on, the BPN and that's -- we think that's a great idea. It's actually early days of even just having announced it, we're having some great success with a whole bunch of different players that are excited to become part of that network. It's essentially a new payments network. We're creating a new payments network that we think it'll enable it much easier for suppliers. We think it'll make it easier not -- for them to not only accept payments, but optimize their payments, reconcile all the different data they have in their business. We've also talked about some of the partnerships we have with Bottomline. Bottomline is a partner with ours in the virtual card business that I mentioned, but they're also a partner of ours in launching B2B Connect. B2B Connect is an entirely new business that we've built using distributed ledger technology to try to do something that sounds quite simple. It's a very hard problem to solve. But if we do it, we think it will be quite revolutionary, which is to electronify and simplify B2B cross-border payments around the world. And Bottomline has been a great partner in bringing that up, but as has many other banks and other partners around the world of helping us grow that new product. I don't think anyone knows exactly what the silver bullet is going to be if there is one. So our approach to the B2B space is, first, we're very committed to it. We see it as a significant, albeit long-term opportunity. We're very focused on partnering to try to bring the ecosystem together and bring new business models to market that can just make it easier for suppliers and all different parts of the ecosystem to streamline the accounts receivable and accounts payable side of this very stubborn business, as you said.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: I wanted to talk about emerging markets for a second and specifically India, which is, I think, a market that many investors had kind of started to write-off for Visa with a view that maybe there would be some other alternative whether it's a national network or another alternative wallet that can gain a lot of share there instead of Visa. Do you think there's a real opportunity for you to get substantial market position in India over time? What are your conversations with people like the regulators and government in India like? And maybe just talk a little bit about whether you view competitors such as Paytm as competitors mainly or potential partners?

RYAN M. MCINERNEY: India is a very, very dynamic commerce market right now. So let me try to go through the issues that you laid out. And if I don't remember them all, you can remind me. First to start with our position. We have a very strong position in India. More than 50% share of both credit and debit. So we feel very good about our position. Second, after demonetization, which was quite a disruptive force in Indian commerce, we should double the size of our business. We doubled the size of our business post demonetization versus pre demonetization. But I think what's also notable is we've continued to grow the business as fast, if not faster, on this much bigger base. So we feel good about our starting position in India. The business continues to grow at a very healthy rate. But as I said, it's a very, very dynamic market. Lots of new competition emerging, especially enabled by UPI and real time payments. You also have Paytm, as you mentioned. We have a very strong domestic player in RuPay and so on and so forth. From the macro opportunity, the opportunity for everybody in India is enormous. There still the overwhelming majority of everything that's bought and sold in India is with cash. We feel really good, to your question, about the relationship that we have with the regulators. We feel really good about the relationship that we have with all of our bank partners and seller partners in India. And to your direct question about Paytm, we absolutely see them as a partner. We have lots of ideas that we think we could help Paytm grow its business, grow acceptance in the country, grow issuance and usage and -- as we do many of the other digital players in India. So it's an area where we've had a lot of focus. We've been -- we've made some investments in the country and we're very excited about the opportunity. But there too, the cash in India sometimes can be as stubborn as the B2B payments that you mentioned earlier. So we recognize that it's going to take us a long time to capture all of the opportunity.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Very good. Maybe just to also ask you about Amazon. Clearly they are a major force in e-commerce and a very big partner also of Visa both on the -- as a large merchant as well as an issuer of cobranded cards. So we've heard more and more about Amazon's efforts to kind of do more in payments in general. So how do you think about managing the concentration risk of any partner who's as big as that? And how do you assess the risk of Amazon launching a wallet offering that reaches beyond itself as a merchant?

RYAN M. MCINERNEY: Amazon's a great partner. We have a deep partnership with them in many, many countries around the world. Our -- like our job #1 with a partner like Amazon is to help them deliver what their #1 priority is. And their #1 priority is to deliver a great customer experience. And if you go through all the different capabilities, technologies, solutions and services that we have, we are as active with Amazon as any other partner of trying to put those capabilities to work to help Amazon deliver a great customer experience. And as big as Amazon is, the seller side of our business still remains very, very distributed, not just in this country but all around the world. So I don't think about it exactly in the sense that you described. We're very, very focused on with Amazon or any other big tech platform, partner or commerce enabler, how do we -- going back to maybe where we started the discussion, how do we ensure that they view Visa as the best commerce enablement platform in the world? The simplest, the safest, the easiest to do business with. And if we just continue to deliver on that kind of day in and day out for Amazon and all of these other technology platforms, they're going to use their scarcest resource, which is engineering resources, to focus on great commerce experiences, great buying experiences, building great phones, building great advertising models. Whatever it is they do to drive their business and in hopes that they'll view us as the best commerce partner that they have to both process their transactions, but help deliver great buying experiences. So that's kind of how we think about working with Amazon, but also more broadly with large tech and commerce enablers.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Very good. Unfortunately, I think we're pretty much out of time. So Ryan, thanks for being with us today. We appreciate it.

RYAN M. MCINERNEY: Well, thanks for having me. Thanks, everyone.
