YOU might have missed it – what with the biggest recession since the 1930s and a pandemic going on – but there may be big, and bad, changes happening to a media landscape near you. Right now the Australian government is considering amending the Competition and Consumer Act 2010 to force Google and Facebook to pay local commercial media organisations for the sharing of their content on the digital platforms. The News Media and Digital Platforms Bargaining Code proposed by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission will require the tech and media companies to make terms through “mandatory binding arbitration”. It will also oblige them to divulge parts of their core intellectual property (such Google’s search algorithm). It has been lauded as a world-first in addressing the power imbalance between the platforms and traditional news organisations. Champions such as commission chief Rod Sims argue it’s a simple matter of forcing Google and Facebook to pay a fair price for extracting value from journalism for which they pay nothing. As Sims put it: What this was all about was the imbalance in bargaining power, the market failure that comes from that, and underpayment for news having a detrimental effect on Australian society. Who could argue with that? Even federal treasurer Josh Frydenberg has described it as “a question of fairness”. But from an economic standpoint the whole bargaining code is hopelessly confused. It fails to properly understand the source of competitive pressure for media companies, and why they have lost revenues over the last 15 years. Mandatory binding arbitration between tech and media companies is also a completely inappropriate policy tool to achieve the public policy goal of fostering high-quality journalism. As I have written about in detail for the Stigler Center at the University of Chicago Booth School of Business, making the code law risks doing serious harm to Australian consumers while shovelling money to large media companies like Nine Entertainment and News Corp Australia. Faced with the prospect of having to divulge key intellectual property, it would not be surprising if Google and Facebook simply prefer not to be in the Australian market. Millions of Australians using Google, YouTube and Facebook will lose out. Media revenue sinking Between 2002 and 2018, consulting firm AlphaBeta estimates total annual revenue for Australian newspapers fell from A$4.4 billion to A$3.0 billion. Almost all of this was due to lost classified advertising revenue, worth A$1.5 billion in 2002 but just A$200 million in 2018. “That’s Google’s fault,” you might cry. Actually no. The vast bulk of lost classified advertising revenue was due to online “pure-plays” such as Seek, Domain and Carsales. Google and Facebook took basically none of this revenue. The media companies were sitting on a gold mine of classified advertising. Then there was massive technological disruption due to the internet and smart phones. That, as they say in the classics, is show business. It doesn’t justify making companies who happened to succeed in an adjacent space at the same time fork over a chunk of their revenues. But aren’t tech companies ‘stealing’ content? If big tech companies were somehow allowing you and me free access to content we would otherwise have to pay for, there might be a case to answer. That would be like Google Maps not only giving you directions to a restaurant but the means to also avoid paying for your meal. But using a search engine does not allow you to get free meals, nor to get around a news organisation’s pay wall. In fact, having their content pop up in search results, or shared on social media, helps Australian media companies to attract readers and sell subscriptions – something that now accounts for roughly half the revenues of some leading players such as The Australian. All you get for “free” is a snippet of a line or two from the search. For instance, when I searched for news about recently deceased US Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, I got this: If you can figure out the full content of the article from that snippet, you should be using your superpowers for other, more lucrative purposes. Beware the politics There is a very real risk this misguided code will end up becoming law. An overzealous regulator has proposed something that stands to benefit the big media companies, who are – not surprisingly – strongly for it. Those same media companies have huge influence over public perceptions and the fate of politicians. It will be a brave elected representative who pushes back on the proposed code and draft legislation. But if politicians were serious about resolving the real issue at stake in all of this, they would act more directly. Like newspapers all around the world, Australian media and journalists are under pressure – and one thing most people agree on is that high-quality news and journalism is critical to a well-functioning democracy. Whatever the market forces that have slashed the funding of such journalism, there is a strong case for government intervention. But if the Australian government wants to subsidise high-quality journalism, it should do it itself. With the 10-year bond rate less than 1%, it would cost the government just A$18 million a year to fund the interest bill on A$2 billion of media subsidies a year. That’s 72 cents per Australian a year. And all without driving away the hugely valuable services of companies like Google and Facebook that Australian consumers love. The ACCC's News Media Bargaining Code may not be the silver bullet the media industry is looking for, argues UNSW Professor of Economics, Richard Holden in this crossposting from The Conversation. If the government is serious about helping the industry, th...

The ACCC's News Media Bargaining Code may not be the silver bullet the media industry is looking for, argues UNSW Professor of Economics, Richard Holden in this crossposting from The Conversation. If the government is serious about helping the industry, they should be acting much more directly. You might have missed it – what with the biggest recession since the 1930s and a pandemic going on – but there may be big, and bad, changes happening to a media landscape near you. Right now the Australian government is considering amending the Competition and Consumer Act 2010 to force Google and Facebook to pay local commercial media organisations for the sharing of their content on the digital platforms. Jeff Chiu/AP The News Media and Digital Platforms Bargaining Code proposed by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission will require the tech and media companies to make terms through “mandatory binding arbitration”. It will also oblige them to divulge parts of their core intellectual property (such Google’s search algorithm). It has been lauded as a world-first in addressing the power imbalance between the platforms and traditional news organisations. Champions such as commission chief Rod Sims argue it’s a simple matter of forcing Google and Facebook to pay a fair price for extracting value from journalism for which they pay nothing. As Sims put it : What this was all about was the imbalance in bargaining power, the market failure that comes from that, and underpayment for news having a detrimental effect on Australian society. Who could argue with that? Even federal treasurer Josh Frydenberg has described it as “a question of fairness”. But from an economic standpoint the whole bargaining code is hopelessly confused. It fails to properly understand the source of competitive pressure for media companies, and why they have lost revenues over the last 15 years. Mandatory binding arbitration between tech and media companies is also a completely inappropriate policy tool to achieve the public policy goal of fostering high-quality journalism. As I have written about in detail for the Stigler Center at the University of Chicago Booth School of Business, making the code law risks doing serious harm to Australian consumers while shovelling money to large media companies like Nine Entertainment and News Corp Australia. Faced with the prospect of having to divulge key intellectual property, it would not be surprising if Google and Facebook simply prefer not to be in the Australian market. Millions of Australians using Google, YouTube and Facebook will lose out. Media revenue sinking Between 2002 and 2018, consulting firm AlphaBeta estimates total annual revenue for Australian newspapers fell from A$4.4 billion to A$3.0 billion. Almost all of this was due to lost classified advertising revenue, worth A$1.5 billion in 2002 but just A$200 million in 2018. “That’s Google’s fault,” you might cry. Actually no. The vast bulk of lost classified advertising revenue was due to online “pure-plays” such as Seek, Domain and Carsales. Google and Facebook took basically none of this revenue. The media companies were sitting on a gold mine of classified advertising. Then there was massive technological disruption due to the internet and smart phones. That, as they say in the classics, is show business. It doesn’t justify making companies who happened to succeed in an adjacent space at the same time fork over a chunk of their revenues. But aren’t tech companies ‘stealing’ content? If big tech companies were somehow allowing you and me free access to content we would otherwise have to pay for, there might be a case to answer. That would be like Google Maps not only giving you directions to a restaurant but the means to also avoid paying for your meal. But using a search engine does not allow you to get free meals, nor to get around a news organisation’s pay wall. In fact, having their content pop up in search results, or shared on social media, helps Australian media companies to attract readers and sell subscriptions – something that now accounts for roughly half the revenues of some leading players such as The Australian. All you get for “free” is a snippet of a line or two from the search. For instance, when I searched for news about recently deceased US Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, I got this: If you can figure out the full content of the article from that snippet, you should be using your superpowers for other, more lucrative purposes. Beware the politics There is a very real risk this misguided code will end up becoming law. An overzealous regulator has proposed something that stands to benefit the big media companies, who are – not surprisingly – strongly for it. Those same media companies have huge influence over public perceptions and the fate of politicians. It will be a brave elected representative who pushes back on the proposed code and draft legislation. But if politicians were serious about resolving the real issue at stake in all of this, they would act more directly. Like newspapers all around the world, Australian media and journalists are under pressure – and one thing most people agree on is that high-quality news and journalism is critical to a well-functioning democracy. Whatever the market forces that have slashed the funding of such journalism, there is a strong case for government intervention. But if the Australian government wants to subsidise high-quality journalism, it should do it itself. With the 10-year bond rate less than 1%, it would cost the government just A$18 million a year to fund the interest bill on A$2 billion of media subsidies a year. That’s 72 cents per Australian a year. And all without driving away the hugely valuable services of companies like Google and Facebook that Australian consumers love. urn:contentItem:5X46-2TM1-DYNN-T35T-00000-00Vitta launches health insurance aimed at startups2019-09-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:12ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONALVitta launches health insurance aimed at startupsBeth Koike

Technology company Vitta, backed by investors like Jorge Paulo Lemann, Armínio Fraga, Maurício Ceschin (ex-Qualicorp) and Andre Street (Stone), has created a health insurance plan to exclusively serve startups, which usually have difficulties hiring the benefit. In addition to serving this public, the product's outstanding feature is a telemedicine service and a network of pre-selected doctors offered through a big tech platform that helps control costs. The new health insurance will be marketed to startup companies at a price 20% lower than the market's norm.

To minimize risk and maintain the claim rate at 70% (percentage considered ideal), Vitta will set up a pool of startups - similarly to what Qualicorp does with trade associations. Eligible startups are those with one to 499 employees. Vitta's health insurance plan was registered at the National Regulatory Agency for Private Health Insurance and Plans (ANS) in partnership with Omint and Unimed insurance operators, which defined a specific network of hospitals and laboratories and will be responsible for the financial reserves required by the regulatory agency. Vitta started to offer its telemedicine services and provider network last November as a consultancy for companies that wanted to manage health insurance for their employees. In this short period, it has won over 70 companies that together have almost 80,000 users of health insurance. "The readjustment in this client base was in average half of the medical inflation", says João Gabriel Alkmin, CEO at Vitta, which has already received an investment of R$35 million. Founded in 2015, Vitta started with a software company in the healthcare industry and reinforced its operations by acquiring Clinic Web, a medical records platform for clinics and hospitals. Over the years, more than 15,000 physicians like Drauzio Varella, a star doctor in Brazil, began to use the platform, which enabled Vitta to gather a vast database. "We gathered the best physicians who have the best clinical outcomes and set up a network. Their remuneration is up to 25% higher," Mr. Alkmin says. With Vitta's platform, patients can have an initial consultation through WhatsApp with doctors who already have access to the patient's health history. Then, the user is referred to a specialist or emergency room, if applicable. The platform itself schedules the appointment according to the location and available time of the patient. "This happened to me. I had a sore throat, I had constantly problems with it. On the third day, with a slightly more advanced infection, I talked to the doctor by WhatsApp instead of going to the emergency room as I normally do. I sent a picture of my throat through the app. The case required an appointment with an expert, whose schedule was promptly scheduled at the end of that same day and in the same neighborhood. In addition, the specialist doctor already knew my entire health history, including the sore throat tablet I was using," Mr. Alkmin says.

urn:contentItem:5CY2-JC61-JDPT-T17T-00000-00VIVEK RANADIVE, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, TIBCO, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE REGARDING SPORTS, MATH, AND INDIA2014-08-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:12ZLexisNexisVIVEK RANADIVE, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, TIBCO, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE REGARDING SPORTS, MATH, AND INDIA

August 18, 2014

NEWS PROGRAM

VIVEK RANADIVE, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, TIBCO,

TOM KEENE, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: We are thrilled to bring you today one of America's great success stories in digital science, in computing. Vivek Ranadive joins us from TIBCO. He's also got a side job as an owner of a basketball team. His balance sheet has been adjusted by Steven Ballmer.

I mean sports, as you know, with your heritage in India, is a great solution for the Indian culture, whether it's cricket, as an example, or basketball within America. We have seen so much animosity before Mr. Ballmer at the Clippers. What would you like to see the NBA do this season and particularly in the opening of the season to help America heal or come together?

VIVEK RANADIVE, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, TIBCO: Well, I thought that our commissioner Adam Silver acted decisively and very, very quickly. And I welcome Steve into the NBA fraternity.

I think it's going to be a fantastic season for the NBA. It's a global sport. We're taking our team to China this offseason, the preseason. And I just expect a lot of the troubles of the past to be behind us.

KEENE: Within this and within what we see in Ferguson, Missouri, sport has always brought America together. Somewhat reluctantly--

RANADIVE: Right.

KEENE: I can remember some of that as a kid. What needs to be done right now given the events of the past week?

RANADIVE: Well, we actually have a player Ben McLemore who's from the St. Louis area. He had great sympathy for the protesters. And he's been posting to Instagram. He's actually in China right now representing the Kings.

KEENE: Mm-hmm.

RANADIVE: And I think full transparency is what everybody is asking for. And, as you said, sport is the great unifier. All we care about in basketball is do we have game? And that's really what America is about.

ADAM JOHNSON, HOST, BLOOMBERG TELEVISION: Well, you talk about a great unifier, I remember when Yao Ming because the first Chinese player in the NBA and you have now just brought in the first India player, Sim Bhullar, if I've got his name right. He's like 7'5 and 360 pounds. How's this going to change the game?

RANADIVE: Well, I believe that basketball could be one of the most popular sports in India. I have this vision -- I call it NBA 3.0, making basketball the global sport of the 21st century. And markets like India and China are going to help make it that.

KEENE: So TIBCO didn't get comp tickets to the World Cup right?

RANADIVE: No, no, no.

(LAUGHTER)

RANADIVE: We are using TIBCO technology. In many ways, a basketball team is like any other business. It's a social network-type of perishable inventory. And whether you're selling basketball tickets, airline tickets, banking products--

KEENE: Did you really end up in Boston with $50 in your pocket before you went to MIT? Is that story true or did they make that up for you?

RANADIVE: Well, that is true. We have the rupee isn't a convertible currency.

KEENE: Right.

RANADIVE: So you could only have a little bit converted. And so I had about $50 when I showed up.

KEENE: Very good. I hope you didn't switch it at American Express, because you would have gotten killed back then. Vivek Ranadive with us from TIBCO. We have so much to talk about, about his success in computers as well.

0710

(BREAK)

0724

SCARLET FU, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: Vivek Ranadive, you played a big role in digitizing Wall Street. So when you hear about the banks recovering, resurging really, what are your thoughts in terms of how much more they should be utilizing technology?

RANADIVE: Well, I think that more than regulation a bigger threat to the banks is technology. And the bank of the future will probably have no walls. It will be a social network attached to a computer program. And so I don't think they use a lot of technology right now. I think the best is yet to come.

FU: The best is yet to come, Vivek Ranadive, our guest host for the hour.

0725

(BREAK)

0729

KEENE: Good morning, everyone. "This Matters Now" to our guest host. Vivek Ranadive runs TIBCO. They are the bridge for countless big companies interacting with customers. Think Citigroup Asia and Delta Airlines, just as two examples.

Mr. Ranadive landed in Cambridge with the proverbial $50 and dreams. After MIT, after corporate success, he still knows math is what matters. This is a major American debate. People will say you, Raghuram Rajan, now the head of the Central Bank in India out of Booth School, Chicago and others. This is easy for those Indians. How do we make this easy for Americans who seem to have a math phobia?

RANADIVE: Well, I believe that math is going to trump science, so it's essential that we have a strong math curriculum for kids growing up. And you can make math fun and you can make it interesting.

KEENE: You can make it fun is the heart of the matter.

RANADIVE: Yeah, in fact, you can have fantasy sports, which is all math. Everything ends up being a math problem, so whether you're trying to win a basketball, find a cure for cancer, prevent power outages, prevent lost baggage, all math problems.

KEENE: I am absolutely fascinated as a leader in the NBA, as an owner of the Sacramento Kings. The math people say America's a jockocracy. The jockocracy say math's going to get me nowhere. You're one of the few people in the nation to truly bridge this gap.

RANADIVE: Well, I believe that all the answers are in the data. We're now living at a time when we generated ten times as much data in the last couple of years as has existed in the history of mankind. So if you can find the patterns, those patterns will give answers. So math is essential.

KEENE: Math's essential for those that value your company as well. You have stated that you feel your company's undervalued. There's been all sorts of discussion of who would take out your TIBCO. Hewlett Packard, I think of IBM. Seems like IBM buys a company about every 8 hours. What kind of business would take out TIBCO and give it a proper valuation?

RANADIVE: Well, I can't say, but TIBCO is a valuable franchise we're the leaders in integration, we're the leaders in big data. Those are two of the top three priorities for most companies right now. So it's viewed as a valuable company by all the giants.

KEENE: Within that and the other mystery as we go into the autumn of 2014, is cloud-itis. Everybody's into the cloud. When you hear people that have no idea what the cloud is, talking about the cloud, how do you respond to that?

RANADIVE: Well, I think a lot of things will be put in the cloud, but perhaps not everything. And so most companies will end up with what I call a hybrid cloud. Where there will be some things in the cloud, but some things by government regulation are required to be on premise. And what TIBCO does is we provide integration so all of that works together.

KEENE: Right. Is the cloud any different than the fad of big data? Or the fad of nanosphere? I mean, are we going to have over investment in the cloud or more importantly mal-investment (ph)?

RANADIVE: Well, just like any other bubble, you go through these cycles where the latest buzzword becomes the next big thing. But the cloud is very much here to stay. So the way that people will consume technology will be through cloud-based services.

KEENE: How do you respond within TIBCO's work to the idea that all the computer jobs go to Asia, all the computer jobs go to India. Is that true?

RANADIVE: Well, I think that a lot of the jobs do go to Asia. But typically they're lower on the value chain and so most of the innovation is still happening in Silicon Valley and it's a win-win situation. So it's really not a win-lose.

KEENE: OK, I've got about 8 more questions. We didn't even get to these. Vivek Ranadive with us as well.

0733

(BREAK)

0738

KEENE: Well, part of that, and Vivek Ranadive with us with TIBCO and from India, is our diplomacy with India. The drama of Mr. Modi visiting Nepal as his first visit. Describe the symbolism of India's nascent diplomacy with the United States.

RANADIVE: The Indian community both over here as well as all Indians are very excited about Modi right now. And so the Indians are looking to how the United States reacts to Modi. And it's well known that he didn't have a visa to travel here before.

KEENE: Yes.

RANADIVE: And so throwing out the welcome mat for him is viewed as extremely important by Indians right now.

KEENE: And I would suggest within many cultures, you don't do this by telephone or by technology.

FU: It's got to be in person.

KEENE: You've got to go.

JOHNSON: Which is why Secretary Kerry has been traveling extensively.

KEENE: A little busy.

FU: Yeah. Maybe too much for one person, some might say.

0738

(BREAK)

0744

KEENE: Well, Vivek Ranadive with us who does computer systems for the likes, this is right up your alley isn't it?

RANADIVE: Well, it is. And retail is nothing more than a social network tied to perishable inventory. And every retail is in danger of getting "Amazoned" and this is the real threat that all of these companies have.

KEENE: I mean, there it is across any number of businesses.

0744

(BREAK)

0749

KEENE: TIBCO has been doing big data for years. Vivek Ranadive, Founder, Chief Executive Officer of TIBCO. Well, he knows that your LOB needs SAAS. Is that enough jargon for you?

He also respectfully suggests that the big data craze is baloney and what's needed is fast data. And I guess it's something that Bloomberg lives every single day. You need those two seconds beforehand versus the big data after the fact. You're living this aren't you?

RANADIVE: That's right. Many of the 20th century companies would have you believe that big data = big database. But those companies tell you that you've lost the customer after the customer leaves. Or that you have a power outage when you're already sitting in darkness.

And with fast data, we prevent the customer from walking out the door. We want to make the customer the offer before he leaves the aisle, not six months after he leaves.

KEENE: Well, let's talk about the aisle down the airplane. If I'm on a Delta Airlines, you represent Delta Airlines as one of your customers. What do you sell Delta Airlines or Citigroup or anybody else on fast data?

RANADIVE: So if there is a weather delay, then with slow data what would happen is that the entire airline value chain would be disrupted.

KEENE: No, I go get a large Starbucks, have three cups of coffee. And then the three hour flight, you're awake.

JOHNSON: What about the Cinnabon?

KEENE: That's right the Cinnabon.

RANADIVE: They know everything that's happening in real time. They can combine that with historical information about you. And they can give you something to make you happy even before you have a chance to become unhappy.

JOHNSON: When you say make me happy, does that mean they're going to try to sell me something or they're going to give me information? An article I might find interesting and want to read?

RANADIVE: Well, it could be information, it could perishable inventory they have. So if you're sitting at one of my games and you tweet you had cold pizza, I'd pick that up and I know that you're coming to the next game, you don't have parking, your kids are there, my hot dogs will go bad. So rather than waste the hot dogs or the parking, we give that to you and you're happy even before you become unhappy.

KEENE: Within this, Scarlet, we talked earlier about Hewlett Packard and IBM to get this conversation started on the future of TIBCO. Why is big tech so cheap? Every person including Adam Parker that comes on here says big tech is cheap?

FU: The non-social media tech company.

KEENE: Yeah. Why is big tech so inexpensively priced?

RANADIVE: I think that that's not something that should be the case. I think there's a lot of frenzy right now around companies that lose large amounts of money and they have crazy multiples. And many of the big tech companies are highly profitable, they have good cash flow. But they don't seem to be viewed as the sexy investments.

But I do believe that there is an argument to be made that many of the older companies will get replaced and so there is some justification for that line of thinking.

FU: Well, a lot of activist investors have looked at these old tech companies thinking there's a lot of opportunity there. I know that Presidium Investment Management said that it wanted to actively engage TIBCO's board in dialogue. Can you give us an update on that?

RANADIVE: Well, not really. I think that activists have been in Apple, Microsoft, Yahoo, Adobe, EMC, and I think that if you have a profitable company, that's basically well-run, you can be a target of activists. If you have a company that loses large amounts of money and has a crazy multiple, then there's nothing that the activist would do with a company like that.

KEENE: It is August. People are taking the GMATs; they're getting smarter. You were a Baker Scholar at the Harvard Business School. That's the pantheon. That's the LeBron James--

FU: This was after MIT.

KEENE: Yeah. The LeBron James of NBA. What should someone study within an MBA curricula? My guess is more math, more acuity and that's not there is it?

RANADIVE: Well, this last year we looked at 30 gigabytes of data, which is more data than had been generated in the entire history of the NBA just for our Sacramento Kings. So basketball to me is really a big data problem. In fact when I coach my daughter's basketball team. I converted it into a math equation and I believe that how you win games is really a math problem.

KEENE: Should LeBron have gone to Sacramento?

RANADIVE: We would have loved to--

(LAUGHTER)

JOHNSON: Yeah, I can only imagine. Hey, how do you use those 30 gigabytes of data to make my experience better when I go to watch your Sacramento Kings?

RANADIVE: So once you opt in, we know everything about you. And we pick up everything that you put out. So we can give you an experience that's extremely customized to you. Your kids could be with you. We know what your likes are. We know what your dislikes are.

JOHNSON: So literally if I tweet next Tuesday I'm with my best bud and we're at bah-bah-bah-bum, somehow that gets stored and you use that information?

RANADIVE: That's right. So, like I said earlier, even if you say you had cold pizza or you are with your bud, we know everything. And at the root of everything we have what we call a psychological router where we can take sentiment and figure out what kind of actions will convert that into intention and then into action. So again it's all about marrying the social network to the perishable inventory we have.

JOHNSON: I don't know if I should be scared or think this is really cool. Because literally you're using, I'm putting all this out there on social media but you're actually using it.

FU: It's a little too late for that if you're putting that out.

JOHNSON: Yeah, right.

urn:contentItem:5XWF-XVN1-F066-M484-00000-00Vivendi/Universal Music : Un air de conglomérat2020-01-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:12ZLexisNexisARTICLEVivendi/Universal Music : Un air de conglomératLES ECHOS

L'accord avec Tencent donne de la visibilité à la valeur d'actifs de Vivendi, pas à sa décote boursière.


Double (Vivendi)

« La musique réconforte le coeur et nous met dans de bonnes dispositions ». Vivendi avait pu se convaincre de la justesse du proverbe chinois bien avant de céder jusqu'à 20 % d'Universal Music Group (UMG) à un consortium dirigé par une « Big Tech » de l'empire du Milieu, Tencent. Le numéro un mondial de la musique enregistrée avait déjà bien couvert les fausses notes de Canal+, grâce à sacroissance soutenue. Désormais, il accrédite sa valorisation stratégique, même s'il lui faudra passer le diapason des régulateurs, ce qui n'est pas joué d'avance, malgré la mise en sourdine des tensions sino-américaines.

Avec ses 30 milliards d'euros confirmés, la filiale n'a presque rien à envier aux 30,6 milliards de sa maison mère. Préciser que les cessions ultérieures se feraient à un prix au minimum identique fait même entendre la petite musique d'une valeur plancher. Comme la dette nette de l'ex Générale des Eaux est compensée par la valeur boursière de ses participations dans Telecom Italia et Mediaset, le reste de la major du divertissement semble s'offrir gratuitement, y compris la chaîne cryptée qui pèse autour de 5 milliards, selon plusieurs analystes. Il y a quand même un sérieux bémol, la décote de conglomérat. De l'ordre de 25 % pour certains évaluateurs, elle pourrait leur sembler moins exagérée, d'autant que la filialeTencent Music Entertainement de Tencent va entrer au capital de la filiale chinoise de UMG. Seule certitude, les rachats d'actions figureront toujours au programme, un instrument aussi du renforcement du contrôle du groupe Bolloré.


À noter

Vivendi a terminé la dernière séance boursière de 2019 en hausse de 0,2 % à 25,82 euros. Tencent Music Entertainment, qui fait partie du consortium monté par sa maison mère pour entrer au capital de Universal Music, a progressé de 0,6 % à Wall Street. Tencent et ses alliés vont acheter 10 % du capital et ont une option sur 10 % supplémentaire, jusqu'au 15 janvier 2021. L'investissement total représente moins de 2 % de la capitalisation boursière de Tencent, qui s'élève à 410 milliards d'euros, près de 14 fois celle de Vivendi.

urn:contentItem:5V73-CNY1-JCMN-Y0V9-00000-00Vladimir Putin calls new Ukrainian church 'dangerous politicking'2019-01-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:12ZLexisNexisVladimir Putin calls new Ukrainian church 'dangerous politicking'Seraphim Hanisch

Jan 18, 2019( The Duran: http://theduran.com Delivered by Newstex) Via Breitbart[1] In sworn testimony, Google CEO Sundar Pichai told Congress last month that his company does not'manually intervene'[2]on any particular search result. Yet an internal discussion thread leaked to Breitbart News reveals Google regularly intervenes in search results on its YouTube video platform - including a recent intervention that pushed pro-life videos out of the top ten search results for 'abortion.' The term 'abortion' was added to a 'blacklist' file for 'controversial YouTube queries,' which contains a list of search terms that the company considers sensitive. According to the leak, these include some of these search terms related to: abortion, abortions, the Irish abortion referendum, Democratic Congresswoman Maxine Waters, and anti-gun activist David Hogg.

The existence of the blacklist was revealed in an internal Google discussion thread leaked to Breitbart News by a source inside the company who wishes to remain anonymous. A partial list of blacklisted terms was also leaked to Breitbart by another Google source. In the leaked discussion thread, a Google site reliability engineer hinted at the existence of more search blacklists, according to the source. 'We have tons of white- and blacklists that humans manually curate,' said the employee. 'Hopefully this isn't surprising or particularly controversial.' Others were more concerned about the presence of the blacklist. According to the source, the software engineer who started the discussion called the manipulation of search results related to abortion a 'smoking gun.' The software engineer noted that the change had occurred following aninquiry from a left-wingSlatejournalist[3]about the prominence of pro-life videos on YouTube, and that pro-life videos were replaced with pro-abortion videos in the top ten results for the search terms following Google's manual intervention. 'TheSlatewriter said she had complained last Friday and then saw different search results before YouTube responded to her on Monday,' wrote the employee. 'And lo and behold, the [changelog] was submitted on Friday, December 14 at 3:17 PM.' The manually downranked items included several videos from Dr. Antony Levatino, a former abortion doctor who is now a pro-life activist. Another video in the top ten featured a woman's personal story of being pressured to have an abortion, while another featured pro-life conservative Ben Shapiro. TheSlatejournalist who complained to Googlereported[4] that these videos previously featured in the top ten, describing them in her story as 'dangerous misinformation.' Since theSlatejournalist's inquiry andGoogle's subsequent intervention, the top search resultsnow[5]feature pro-abortion content from left-wing sources like BuzzFeed, Vice, CNN, andLast Week Tonight With John Oliver.In herreport[6], theSlatejournalist acknowledged that the search results changed shortly after she contacted Google. The manual adjustment of search results by a Google-owned platform contradicts a keyclaim[7]made under oath by Google CEO Sundar Pichai in his congressional testimony earlier this month: that his company does not 'manually intervene on any search result.' A Google employee in the discussion thread drew attention to Pichai's claim, noting that it 'seems like we are pretty eager to cater our search results to the social and political agenda of left-wing journalists.' One of the posts in the discussion also noted that the blacklist had previously been edited to include the search term 'Maxine Waters' after a single Google employee complained the top YouTube search result for Maxine Waters was 'very low quality.' Google's alleged intervention on behalf of a Democratic congresswoman would be further evidence of the tech giant using its resources to prop up the left. Breitbart News previously reported on leaked emails revealing the company targeted pro-Democrat demographics in its get-out-the-vote efforts in 2016. According to the source, a software engineer in the thread also noted that 'a bunch of terms related to the abortion referendum in Ireland' had been added to the blacklist - another change with potentially dramatic consequences on the national policies of a western democracy. youtube_controversial_query_blacklist At least one post in the discussion thread revealed the existence of a file called 'youtube_controversial_query_blacklist,' which contains a list of YouTube search terms that Google manually curates. In addition to the terms 'abortion,' 'abortions,' 'Maxine Waters,' and search terms related to the Irish abortion referendum, a Google software engineer noted that the blacklist includes search terms related to terrorist attacks. (the posts specifically mentions that the 'Strasbourg terrorist attack' as being on the list). 'If you look at the other entries recently added to theyoutube_controversial_query_blacklist(e.g., entries related to the Strasbourg terrorist attack), the addition of abortion seemsout-of-place,' wrote the software engineer, according to the source. After learning of the existence of the blacklist, Breitbart News obtained a partial screenshot of the full blacklist file from a source within Google. It reveals that the blacklist includes search terms related to both mass shootings and the progressive anti-second amendment activist David Hogg. This suggests Google has followed the lead of Democrat politicians, who haverepeatedly pushed tech companies[8]to censor content related to the Parkland school shooting and the Parkland anti-gun activists. It's part of a popular new line of thought in the political-media establishment,which views the public as too stupid to question conspiracy theories for themselves[9]. Here is the partial blacklist leaked to Breitbart:2117 plane crash Russian 2118 plane crash 2119 an-148 2120 florida shooting conspiracy 2121 florida shooting crisis actors 2122 florida conspiracy 2123 florida false flag shooting 2124 florida false flag 2125 fake florida school shooting 2126 david hogg hoax 2127 david hogg fake 2128 david hogg crisis actor 2129 david hogg forgets lines 2130 david hogg forgets his lines 2131 david hogg cant remember his lines 2132 david hogg actor 2133 david hogg cant remember 2134 david hogg conspiracy 2135 david hogg exposed 2136 david hogg lines 2137 david hogg rehearsing 2120 florida shooting conspiracyThe full internal filepath of the blacklist, according to another source, is: //depot/google3/googledata/superroot/youtube/youtube_controversial_query_blacklist Contradictions Responding to a request for comment, a YouTube spokeswoman said the company wants to promote 'authoritative' sources in its search results, but maintained that YouTube is a 'platform for free speech' that 'allow[s]' both pro-life and pro-abortion content. YouTube's full comment:YouTube is a platform for free speech where anyone can choose to post videos, as long as they follow ourCommunity Guidelines[10], which prohibit things like inciting violence and pornography. We apply these policies impartially and we allow both pro-life and pro-choice opinions. Over the last year we've described how we are working tobetter surface news sources[11]across our site for news-related searches and topical information. We've improved our search and discovery algorithms, built new features that clearly label and prominently surface news sources on our homepage and search pages, and introduced information panels to help give users more authoritative sources where they can fact check information for themselves.In the case of the 'abortion' search results, YouTube's intervention to insert 'authoritative' content resulted in the downranking of pro-life videos and the elevation of pro-abortion ones. A Google spokesperson took a tougher line than its YouTube subsidiary, stating that 'Google has never manipulated or modified the search results or content in any of its products to promote a particular political ideology.' However, in the leaked discussion thread, a member of Google's 'trust ...fety' team, Daniel Aaronson, admitted that the company maintains 'huge teams' that work to adjust search results for subjects that are 'prone to hyperbolic content, misleading information, and offensive content' - all subjective terms that are frequently used to suppress right-leaning sources. He also admitted that the interventions weren't confined to YouTube - they included search results delivered via Google Assistant, Google Home, and in rare cases Google 's organic search results. In the thread, Aaronson attempted to explain how search blacklisting worked. He claimed that highly specific searches would generate non-blacklisted results, even controversial ones. But the inclusion of highly specific terms in the YouTube blacklist, like 'David Hogg cant remember his lines' - the name of an actual viral video - seems to contradict this. Aaronson's full post is copied below:I work in Trust and Safety and while I have no particular input as to exactly what's happening for YT I can try to explain why you'd have this kind of list and why people are finding lists like these on Code Search. When dealing with abuse/controversial content on various mediums you have several levers to deal with problems. Two prominent levers are 'Proactive' and 'Reactive':Proactive: Usually refers to some type of algorithm/scalable solution to a general problem E.g.: We don't allow straight up porn on YouTube so we create a classifier that detects porn and automatically remove or flag for review the videos the porn classifier is most certain ofReactive: Usually refers to a manual fix to something that has been brought to our attention that our proactive solutions don't/didn't work on and something that is clearly in the realm of bad enough to warrant a quick targeted solution (determined by pages and pages of policies worked on over many years and many teams to be fair and cover necessary scope) E,g.: A website that used to be a good blog had it's domain expire and was purchased/repurposed to spam Search results with autogenerated pages full of gibberish text, scraped images, and links to boost traffic to other spammy sites. It is manually actioned for violating policy These Organic Search policies and the consequences to violating them are public[12] Manually reacting to things is not very scalable, and is not an ideal solution to most problems, so the proactive lever is really the one we all like to lean on. Ideally, our classifiers/algorithm are good at providing useful and rich results to our users while ignoring things at are not useful or not relevant. But we all know, this isn't exactly the case all the time (especially on YouTube). From a user perspective, there are subjects that are prone to hyperbolic content, misleading information, and offensive content. Now, these words are highly subjective and no one denies that. But we can all agree generally, lines exist in many cultures about what is clearly okay vs. what is not okay. E.g. a video of a puppy playing with a toy is probably okay in almost every culture or context, even if it's not relevant to the query. But a video of someone committing suicide and begging others to follow in his/her footsteps is probably on the other side of the line for many folks. While my second example is technically relevant to the generic query of 'suicide', that doesn't mean that this is a very useful or good video to promote on the top of results for that query. So imagine a classifier that says, for any queries on a particular text file, let's pull videos using signals that we historically understand to be strong indicators of quality (I won't go into specifics here, but those signals do exist). We're not manually curating these results, we're just saying 'hey, be extra careful with results for this query because many times really bad stuff can appear and lead to a bad experience for most users'. Ideally the proactive lever did this for us, but in extreme cases where we need to act quickly on something that is so obviously not okay, the reactive/manual approach is sometimes necessary. And also keep in mind, that this is different for every product. The bar for changing classifiers or manual actions on span in organic search isextremelyhigh. However, the bar for things we let our Google Assistant say out loud might be a lot lower. If I search for 'Jews run the banks' - I'll likely find anti-semitic stuff in organic search. As a Jew, I might find some of these results offensive, but they are there for people to research and view, and I understand that this is not a reflection of Google feels about this issue. But if I ask Google assistant 'Why do Jews run the banks' we wouldn't be similarly accepting if it repeated and promoted conspiracy theories that likely pop up in organic search in her smoothing voice. Whether we agree or not, user perception of our responses, results, and answers of different products and mediums can change. And I think many people are used to the fact that organic search is a place where content should be accessible no matter how offensive it might be, however, the expectation is very different on a Google Home, a Knowledge Panel, or even YouTube. These lines are very difficult and can be very blurry, we are all well aware of this. So we've got huge teams that stay cognizant of these facts when we're crafting policies considering classifier changes, or reacting with manual actions - these decisions are not made in a vacuum, but admittedly are also not made in a highly public forum like TGIF or IndustryInfo (as you can imagine, decisions/agreement would be hard to get in such a wide list - image if all your CL's were reviewed by every engineer across Google all the time). I hope that answers some questions and gives a better layer of transparency without going into details about our 'Pepsi formula'. Best, DanielThe fact that Google manually curates politically contentious search results fits in with a wider pattern of political activity on the part of the tech giant. In 2018, Breitbart News exclusively published a leaked video from the company that showedsenior management in dismay at Trump's election victory[13], and pledging to use the company's power to make his populist movement a'hiccup' in history[14]. Breitbart also leaked'The Good Censor,'[15]an internal research document from Google that admits the tech giant is engaged in the censorship of its own products, partly in response to political events. Another leak revealed that employees within the company, including Google's current director of Trust and Safety,tried to kick Breitbart News off Google's market-dominating online ad platforms[16]. Yet another showed Google engaged intargeted turnout operations[17]aimed to boost voter participation in pro-Democrat demographics in 'key states' ahead of the 2016 election. The effort was dubbed a 'silent donation' by a top Google employee. Evidence for Google's partisan activities is now overwhelming.President Trump has previously warned Google[18], as well as other Silicon Valley giants, not to engage in censorship or partisan activities. Google continues to defy him. Allum Bokhari is the senior technology correspondent at Breitbart News.
